description:

I was told to complain to the town if I wanted but that it wouldn't do any good.

It's not the end of the world, but it would have been nice to know about this instead of finding out after starting to make dinner and not being able to light my range.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU)  agrees that the workers should have given you a heads up that the emulation used to help the newly paved adhere to the roadway is a material that will stick to the bottom if your shoes if you walked on it. I am hoping that your dog is OK. I am disappointed  that they did not tell you a head of time.  In my experience in paving I have seen workers always warn constituents about not walking on the street with the emulation placed before paving is to be done. status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The PWD Roadway Repair Contractor is working on your street performing patch paving. It is an important city service for your neighborhood to provide the best permanent repairs of previous utility excavations or potholes. The construction process is to dig out 6.5 inches of material and place 5 inches of dense binder hot mix asphalt in 2 lifts. The dense binder gives the patch its strength but is has large stones and is not conducive to providing a smooth ride, the contractor usually within a week comes back and places 1.5 inches of  the top course. The top course is hot mix asphalt  that provides the smooth ride. The street is leafleted before the work begins where it explains that it is a mufti phase construction operation and you should look at the dates since they will change as each construction phases progresses. Our goal is to allow parking between phases and not post the street for the entire time the work takes place. This is why the contractor repeatedly changes the dates. We spoke to the contractor about his need to be totally accurate when posting and leafleting  for upcoming work. Since this is a patching contract, the contractor may only be on your street for only a short period of time; giving the appearance of not showing up. Sometimes  poor weather, plant breakdowns, or equipment failure occurs which results in the delay of the upcoming work. The CIU spoke to the contractor about his need to do a better job on changing the dates when those situations arise. Any questions you call the City Engineer Tom Mougamian. 617-304-7308. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused.  Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

After a series of changes to lane markings, it has settled to only marking: a left-only arrow near the stop line.

I understand the State DCR likes minimal markings on the roadways, so  I'm suggesting that Boston put perhaps 2 signs maybe spaced 40 and 80 feet ahead of the intersection with a diagram showing left lane for left turn and right lane for straight and right. Thanks.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. When excavating in Massachusetts, its the law to call dig safe and mark out all the underground utilities with paint. This allows the contractor to dig safely and not possibly hit an underground utility line such as the gas line. The paint should wear off over time. If the markings are still there in the next 30-60 days please contact my office. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The PWD Roadway Repair Contractor was working on your street performing patch paving. It is an important city service for your neighborhood to provide the best permanent repairs of previous utility excavations or potholes.  The construction process is to dig out 6.5 inches of material and place 5 inches of dense binder hot mix asphalt in 2 lifts. The dense binder gives the patch its strength but is has large stones and is not conducive to providing a smooth ride, the contractor usually within a week comes back and places 1.5 inches of  the top course. The top course is hot mix asphalt  that provides the smooth ride.  The street is leafleted before the work begins where it explains that it is a mufti phase construction operation and you should look at the dates since they will change as each construction phases progresses.  Our goal is to allow parking between phases and not post the street for the entire time the work takes place. This is why the contractor repeatedly changes the dates. We spoke to the contractor about his need to be totally accurate when posting and leafleting  for upcoming work.  Since this is a patching contract, the contractor may only be on your street for only a short period of time; giving the appearance of not showing up.  Sometimes  poor weather, plant breakdowns, or equipment failure occurs which results in the delay of the upcoming work.  The CIU spoke to the contractor about his need to do a better job on changing the dates when those situations arise.  Any questions you call the City Engineer Tom Mougamian. 617-304-7308. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for bringing this matter to our attention. In order to help us better understand your request for a barrier; please visit the link below to download a request form to provide some background information on your request. Upon receipt of the completed form, engineering staff will review the form and any supporting documentation and perform a site visit for a safety evaluation. Based on the information provided and the site evaluation, we will determine what safety measures (if any) can be implemented in response to your request. Please note that the completion of this form does not guarantee a barrier will be installed. Other safety measures such as signage, lighting, and/or changes to roadway geometry may also be implemented to address safety concerns instead of, or in addition to, your request for a barrier. If you have any questions, please contact the Public Works Department Engineering Division at 617-635-4968 or at pwdengineering@boston.gov.  Again, we appreciate and thank you for your interest in public safety and the welfare of your community. Barrier Request Form:  https://attachments.cityofboston.gov/?f=14990&fid=28a944f9.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. The General Contractor did not have a permit to pour concrete, he did not have a permit to move the fence onto the public sidewalk blocking access. He was shut down and ordered to move the fence back to private property, which he did. He was also told to trim the weeds and pave over the section of sidewalk left with crushed stones. He stated he will trim the weeds early next  and pave the sidewalk section by mid week. Until the sidewalk section is paved he will place a sidewalk closed signs at the nearest crosswalks to alert a person with a disability who may not be able to traverse over the crushed stones. He will NOT be allowed to go back to work until he receives proper permits. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.
